body:
If you build the Accumulo tarball with the Hadoop 3 profile, `-Dhadoop.profile=3`, it will include commons-configuration 1.6. There was a JIRA issue, https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ACCUMULO-4830 , which proposed creating a single binary tarball compatible with both... which might be easy if we bundle everything we need, and have different config templates for Hadoop 2 and 3, which list their class path items directly rather than use wildcards.

When I tried using 1.9.x with Hadoop 3.0.2, it worked as long as I built with the Hadoop 3 profile, but I couldn't get it to work with 3.1.0, and I wasn't able to figure out why.
@ctubbsii Looking at this test in master and it seems to be passing now.  Was this already fixed?
@keith-turner do you think the shell should support the old and new bulk import APIs?
@milleruntime I don't think there's a test for this issue, so I'm not sure what test you're talking about.
The shell has its own API. I don't think we need to confuse it with multiple commands that map to different Java APIs. We can just change its options, for example, to make failure directory optional.
So you are saying have the one command support both?  If you pass a failure directory use the old technique, otherwise use the new one?
You mention AuditMessageIT failing when you changed it to use the new API.
One command, but should use the new implementation if the failure directory isn't specified.

Oh. Sorry for the confusion. That's where I first noticed this issue, but I fixed that to avoid reusing the same directory. The reported behavior still exists, and could affect users of the new API. We don't have a test case for this and I'm not sure what the expected behavior should be. I don't know if it is common to import rfiles from a directory with other stuff in it or whether it should recurse to find more rfiles, or have some other behavior.

Perhaps... but I think it might be better to only use the new one, leaving the failure directory arg as optional, so it doesn't break people who provide one, and give a deprecation warning if they do provide one.

Think we need to worry about backwards compatibility?  The way the CLI options work, I think I am going to have to change the command from:
`importdirectory  <directory> <failureDirectory> true|false`
to
`importdirectory  <directory> true|false [-f <directory>] `
I found the NO_FIXED_ARG_LENGTH_CHECK so I will make the command work with old and new based on number of parameters.

No problem.  I actually just saw this error when testing the new bulk import shell command.  I saw the error happen when you pass an empty directory.  

I think we should just print a debug if the directory is empty or if there other files present.  It seems like an empty directory or having other files present (because of Map Reduce) is not abnormal behavior.
Created user manual documentation for this change at apache/accumulo-website#100

@keith-turner, @milleruntime, Thanks for the initial pass over the PR. It is an involved change and also my first run at modifying a FATE operation. I will begin addressing and modifying the code based on your comments throughout the next several days. I'm sure I will have some questions along the way as well. Please let me know of any additional suggestions or concerns as they come to you.
Updated performance test to use hints apache/accumulo-testing#31

This design shares some similarities with scan executors.

https://accumulo.apache.org/docs/2.x/administration/scan-executors
Functionality added in #549 #571
Removed archive feature in #581
Opened PR #581 to remove archiving

@ctubbsii & @keith-turner, `ServerInfo` was needed because the `Master`, `TabletServer` classes extend `AccumuloServerContext`.  I needed to be able to create an object like `ServerInfo` and use it for setup before creating the Master/TabletServer objects. If instead AccumuloServerContext is passed into the Master/TabletServer constructors, I think I could combine ServerInfo and AccumuloServerContext. Not sure if this should be done in this PR or another one.
I was able to merge ServerInfo and AccumuloServerContext.  ServerInfo is still around but is only used to create ServerContext.

@keith-turner Take a look at my latest changes to CryptoSeErviceFactory in c8310f9.  I changed it to only load the CryptoService once when the factory class is loaded and made getConfigured() just check against the latest config and throw an error if the class changed.  If you think this would work, we also may not need AtomicReference... I am not sure though.

@milleruntime Yeah I don't think the atomic ref is needed after that change.   That change fixes the concurrency issue and it handles multiple config in a predictable way (it only compares the class name and not the opts though... however comparing the opts for each call would inefficient).  More static stuff in Accumulo is unfortunate.  It would be nice to open up a follow on issue to look into removing the static stuff.

> More static stuff in Accumulo is unfortunate. It would be nice to open up a follow on issue to look into removing the static stuff.

I will either rebase or create a follow on to incorporate the creation of CryptoService into the Instance work @mikewalch is currently working on.
I was looking at this code the other day and wondered what this "archive" stuff was all about.  Was there a use case for archiving at one time? Does the latest WAL fixes make this irrelevant?

The archive stuff was created a long time ago to assist in debugging data loss problem observed when running continuous ingest + agitation.   For a  long time there were no data loss problems until recently.   I looked to use this feature recently and noticed it was not properly working.  Now HDFS has trash and this feature is probably no longer needed.  So I think its better to remove it rather than fix it.

I don't know if ZooCache is the right abstraction for this. It would be nice if we had some abstraction for "small consistent persisted cluster-wide state storage" that didn't necessarily expose ZK or our caching layer on top of ZK.
Opened #584 relating to the static objects in CryptoServiceFactory.
@PircDef Are there any more changes you would like to make before I merge this PR?  I feel like it is close but I am going to continue testing today.
I see this issue as an iterative improvement.  If we start returning ZooCache from ClientContext, it will be easier eventually swap it out with something better.
@milleruntime I have no immediate objections.
@ctubbsii, that is the ultimate goal. There are just parts of the code where it's not easy to remove ServerContext.  This is a good intermediate step.
Thanks @bfach10 for the work so far!  I created a new pull request (#590) that addresses comments from the code review on this PR.  I am going to close this PR. Please comment on #590.

> Is there a write-up of what an "exact delete" is and what the overall design of this implementation is?

There is now : apache/accumulo-website#102

There is also what was on the JIRA issue.

>  It would be nice if we had some abstraction for "small consistent persisted cluster-wide state storage" that didn't necessarily expose ZK or our caching layer on top of ZK.

After reading this comment and looking at the changes in #585 that passed server context to metadata util static methods it made me think that hanging more off of server context would be good.  One reason I think its good is that it make discovering what internal operation can be performed on Accumulo much easier (via IDE auto complete).  For example could possibly have code like the following, currently the method `updateTableFlushID` exists as a static method in metadata util class.  Its hard for someone new to find this method.  But with good methods hanging off server context a developer can easily discover a lot w/ IDE.

```java
  serverContext.getTabletDataMutator(extent).updateTableFlushID(zooLock, flushID)
```

For the methods hanging off server context, they could return objects for reading and writing certain types of data.  Below are some possible candidates for abstractions that could hang off server context.  

 * Persistent tablet data (sometimes stored in ZK, usually in metadata table).
 * Delete makers and blips
 * Walogs
 * FATE data
 * Security data

I really like exact deletes. I think it would be a great feature to add.  It just seems more useful if it was done on a per-mutation basis instead of changing the behavior of the table.  It would be nice if users could choose between range and exact deletes.  

If you are looking to improve performance by minimizing seeks for deletes, what about adding the option to turn off deletes for a table at creation time?

After further inspection, most of these classes are util classes, and aren't JUnit test cases, so whether or not they match the pattern is confusing, but not really a problem. Some of them make sense to move into a util package. Others could be renamed, and others (like `TestIngest`) which are used by a lot of other things are probably fine as they are.

The only important tests which aren't running are the `TestProxy*` tests, which weren't running at all, but should be ITs against mini (originally written for MockAccumulo, which was removed in 2.0, but weren't actually running because they were in the wrong directory).
What does `because a tablet id of -1 was written` mean? What is a `-1` supposed to indicate?
@mikewalch and @ctubbsii I agree with your assessments.  I opened #598 based on your comments.

It seems the code is using -1 to indicate an invalid id for all tablets with walog disabled.   When the walog is disabled, tablets get a walog id of -1. As long as the walog is disabled, define tablet events should not be written to the walog.  However I think the define tablet events are being written in some situations.

I'm having a hard time reproducing this when running the test by itself (can't reproduce locally at all). However, I'd like to keep the issue open until I'm sure it's not a problem with our test code.

I renamed FileStuff to FileHelper and created FileOptions class that will hold all the objects.  Everything in FileOptions is public final so we can just pass this immutable object around.  Follow on work could be to replace all the calls to getters with the final public members of FileOptions, but this is a more disruptive change just to eliminate getter methods.
I will merge this since it will be easier for you guys to make changes/give feedback once you can start using it and get that autocomplete going.

@ctubbsii Sorry I missed the notification that you had updated this PR. I updated the getEndRow to getTabletId as requested. I think the constructor was still necessary as it was used in a few places where the extent wasnt clear (to me, anyway) such as RandomizeVolumes

I saw this again and it filled up a 240GB partition with a 96GB file repeating that same message. I've attempted to capture some of the logs to figure out what the server processes were doing at the time. At the very least, this test needs a timeout so it doesn't run forever... and maybe we need to fix the log4j configuration so it collapses repeated messages.

It looks like using this plugin might require us to move to spotbugs (which isn't a bad idea).  It also looks like some more configuration might necessary.  See the docs below:

https://github.com/find-sec-bugs/find-sec-bugs/wiki/Maven-configuration

Yeah I think you are correct.  It looks like spotbugs (the successor to findbugs) is version 3.1.3 where the version of findbugs we are using is 3.0.5.

With those added config files, I am now at least seeing this on a few of our projects:
[INFO] --- findbugs-maven-plugin:3.0.5:findbugs (findbugs) @ accumulo-start ---
[INFO] Fork Value is true
     [java] The following errors occurred during analysis:
     [java]   Unable to locate method java.util.TreeSet.stream()Ljava/util/stream/Stream;
     [java] Analysis errors: 1

So I got the plugin working with the new version of findbugs (aka spotbugs).  Now I just need to triage all the new bugs, which is going to take some time.

To start this is a big one, which I am not sure if we can ignore or not:
[INFO] org.apache.accumulo.start.classloader.AccumuloClassLoader.getClassLoader() creates a org.apache.accumulo.start.classloader.AccumuloClassLoader$2 classloader, which should be performed within a doPrivileged block [org.apache.accumulo.start.classloader.AccumuloClassLoader] At AccumuloClassLoader.java:[line 219] DP_CREATE_CLASSLOADER_INSIDE_DO_PRIVILEGED

[INFO] new org.apache.accumulo.start.classloader.vfs.AccumuloReloadingVFSClassLoader(String, FileSystemManager, ReloadingClassLoader, long, boolean) creates a org.apache.accumulo.start.classloader.vfs.PostDelegatingVFSClassLoader classloader, which should be performed within a doPrivileged block [org.apache.accumulo.start.classloader.vfs.AccumuloReloadingVFSClassLoader] At AccumuloReloadingVFSClassLoader.java:[line 186] DP_CREATE_CLASSLOADER_INSIDE_DO_PRIVILEGED

[INFO] new org.apache.accumulo.start.classloader.vfs.AccumuloReloadingVFSClassLoader(String, FileSystemManager, ReloadingClassLoader, long, boolean) creates a org.apache.commons.vfs2.impl.VFSClassLoader classloader, which should be performed within a doPrivileged block [org.apache.accumulo.start.classloader.vfs.AccumuloReloadingVFSClassLoader] At AccumuloReloadingVFSClassLoader.java:[line 184] DP_CREATE_CLASSLOADER_INSIDE_DO_PRIVILEGED

[INFO] org.apache.accumulo.start.classloader.vfs.AccumuloReloadingVFSClassLoader$2.run() creates a org.apache.accumulo.start.classloader.vfs.PostDelegatingVFSClassLoader classloader, which should be performed within a doPrivileged block [org.apache.accumulo.start.classloader.vfs.AccumuloReloadingVFSClassLoader$2] At AccumuloReloadingVFSClassLoader.java:[line 123] DP_CREATE_CLASSLOADER_INSIDE_DO_PRIVILEGED

[INFO] org.apache.accumulo.start.classloader.vfs.AccumuloReloadingVFSClassLoader$2.run() creates a org.apache.commons.vfs2.impl.VFSClassLoader classloader, which should be performed within a doPrivileged block [org.apache.accumulo.start.classloader.vfs.AccumuloReloadingVFSClassLoader$2] At AccumuloReloadingVFSClassLoader.java:[line 121] DP_CREATE_CLASSLOADER_INSIDE_DO_PRIVILEGED

[INFO] org.apache.accumulo.start.classloader.vfs.AccumuloVFSClassLoader.getClassLoader() creates a org.apache.commons.vfs2.impl.VFSClassLoader classloader, which should be performed within a doPrivileged block [org.apache.accumulo.start.classloader.vfs.AccumuloVFSClassLoader] At AccumuloVFSClassLoader.java:[line 219] DP_CREATE_CLASSLOADER_INSIDE_DO_PRIVILEGED

@ctubbsii Thanks for the feedback.  I updated the plugin in the execution section as well and got even more hits.  I am not sure why only some bugs would show up by updating the plugin dependency but having the maven plugin executing the old one. Perhaps some of the changes between the versions on how the plugin executes.

I am also not sure the best way to handle this update since its becoming a lot of changes.  Before I did the above, I had made it through start and saw 109 bugs in core.

I'm not sure I understood what you were saying about Maven executing the "old one".

As for all the bugs in core... you could just temporarily add a blanket exclude to the remaining modules' exclude-filter.xml for all SECURITY type bugs, in order to work through one module at a time.
Checkout 3151de8d.  I missed updating the plugin execution section of the pom to use spotbugs.  Once I did this, I saw even more bugs.
OK so it looks like with my last update (3151de8) it is now properly executing the security bugs plugin.  I am now seeing security bugs show up.
Creating a follow on ticket for using the sec-bugs plugin.  I am going to use this PR just for upgrading findbugs to spotbugs.

It's probably a good idea to separate out the spotbugs upgrade from the find-sec-bugs. The renames look good to me, and everything else you've done looks good to me, but I have an extra commit I'm going to add to this PR to eliminate some of the other matches from grepping for "findbugs". In particular, there are some "findbugs mitigations" that were done and mentioned in comments, that I think there are better solutions for, so I'm going to do those, and include them here, so that we can eliminate all references to findbugs in this transition.

@milleruntime I added commit 0ce8d44d17d5d2aed8432b05fea8453e019e45e0 to include my review feedback. With that (and rebased on top of #619) all looks good to me. Feel free to squash my commit in with everything else.
Cool sounds good.

If you'd like to be added to the contributors page at https://accumulo.apache.org/people , please submit a pull request to update the website page at https://github.com/apache/accumulo-website/blob/master/pages/people.md with your details (please mention #620 )
It's possible these were caused by reintroduction of deleted data bugs that were fixed in 1.9.2. It's also possible there's some problem with the metadata scanner used to read the tablet information.

I seem to remember there being some debate about it at the time, but I thought I had made a convincing case for it. I believe it had something to do with making it easier to manage the class path, either by unpacking a newer tarball on top of another (probably a bad idea anyway), or something to do with our scripts being broken every time we bumped the dependency version.

I think going back to the explicit version numbers are fine, but I'd like to first review the history to see if there's any still valid reason why we shouldn't do that.

how many threads are running at the same time?

On Thu, Aug 30, 2018 at 2:49 AM Noam Ivri <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> I have a table with about 4M rows in Accumulo, which is grouped to about
> 90K entities with different rowIds, and it takes about 10 sec to scan all
> the table from the Java API when I scan with large rowId range or ranges. I
> have also tried BatchScan ranges where each rowId is its own range. Scan
> -np on the Accumulo shell gives similar result.
> I have tried it with different configurations on very strong machines @aws
> <https://github.com/aws> and the performance does not get better than
> about 10s. Is that reasonable? It seems very slow but maybe that is what
> Accumulo can do. Does anyone have experience with such queries? Using:
> Accumulo 1.7.4 Hadoop 2.8.1 4vCPU, 16GB RAM (AWS m5d.xlarge), 5 servers
> running Accumulo tservers and Hadoop data nodes, one name node running
> Accumulo master.
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/apache/accumulo/issues/624>, or mute the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AACqRSetKNZLZ4_Wq4UhlEZadzX9kbsbks5uV4rbgaJpZM4WS3-A>
> .
>
In the BatchScan? I have tired 10,100,500 and 1000...  this didn't provide much improvement

Have you enabled [caching](https://accumulo.apache.org/docs/2.0/administration/caching) for the table? Below is the command to do this in the shell...

```
config -t mytable -s table.cache.block.enable=true
```

There are other [tips for improving performance](https://accumulo.apache.org/docs/2.0/troubleshooting/performance) in the 2.0 documentation that should probably apply to 1.7.4.

It sounds like you are doing a full table scan with your queries, which is always going to be slower and you should avoid.  Providing a Range on BatchScanner should greatly narrow the focus of queries to a smaller subset of data.  Have you set any split points on your data?   This step on the tour is a good introduction: https://accumulo.apache.org/tour/ranges-splits/
Does anyone have objections if I merge this?
I don't have any objections, but I did intend to review it, @mikewalch .

Thank you so much for working on this, @mikewalch ! I think this is going to be a huge user experience improvement. Everyone hates XML and this is so much better. Adding the tool to help migrate is a big plus also.
What does this fix?
Can you provide a description regarding why this is desired? I don't understand the benefit of hiding these error messages from the user, especially the way we use the bean validator.
The error messages are not being sanitized by the underlying framework so they could be used for XSS.

Do they include user input, or just our own messages? I thought just the latter, so XSS wouldn't be an issue. It's fine to drop them, though... I think users should never see those error messages anyway, if they are using the web service with links from our own monitor app, because we'll never provide a link which generates such an error message (we shouldn't anyway).

I tested it out running uno locally and this will work in firefox:
http://localhost:9995/tservers?s=%3Cscript%3Ewindow.alert(%27Got%20ya!%27)%3C/script%3E
There was discussion on the user list that may be of interest as well.  https://s.apache.org/rXId and https://s.apache.org/8QS3

Merged:

commit 4b3273bd61e3fbc792069a07fdae37e59151f1a2
Author: Ivan Bella <ivan@bella.name>
Date:   Sat Aug 25 21:07:44 2018 -0400

    ACCUMULO-4854 : DfsLogger exceptions (#616)
       Removed translation of ClosedChannelException to a LogClosedException in the write method as that is done by callers of the method.

Saw `ShellServerIT.testCreateTableWithLocalityGroupsBadArguments()` test fail with this change. Looks like `DefaultParser` isn't a direct substitute for the deprecated `BasicParser`. It seems to handle some parsing errors differently... perhaps throwing an `IllegalArgumentException` when `BasicParser` would have error'd differently.

This could be related to: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/38964866/defaultparser-in-commons-cli-doesnt-behave-like-the-deprecated-parsers

thanks for all the answers. I have set splits on the tables, which helps very little, since its  not a resource issue.(CPU/ Mem/ IO are all under utilized)
Table scan was just a test and the real problem is slow queries. I do use ranges (large ones as needed) and it takes several seconds. I was trying to understand if its reasonable time?,Rational DB of this size (a few million rows) will do it in a split of a second.

@jmark99 I am finished reviewing this.  These changes look great.  The only major outstanding concern I have is making the test use the tables created in these new ways a bit to ensure they are functional.
@jmark99  is there a test the creates an offline table?
@mikewalch  can you provide some context for why you made this change?
@keith-turner , there is a test for creating offline tables in ShellServerIT
@keith-turner, thanks for the review. I've changed a couple of the variable/enum names based upon your comments. I'll work to create tests to verify functionality as outlined above.

The related Hadoop issue is https://jira.apache.org/jira/browse/HADOOP-11393

While things were working, I was getting warnings from Hadoop when using HADOOP_PREFIX.
Ah ok, the test in ShellServerIT for offline looks good.
I'm working on this.

It looks like the reason why it failed with the `DefaultParser` was because the `BasicParser` seems to require long options to have two dashes `--` and the `DefaultParser` permits a single dash `-` with long opts. Our test case assumed it would fail. I'll just delete that test case, since I think it's fine to follow the `BasicParser` parsing.
Splitting these commits up so this PR is easier to review... un momento, por favor
@keith-turner, I added an additional IT test to CreateInitialSplitsIT to address the steps you outlined above. If it looks ok do you think we are ready to close this PR?
@jmark99 It looks like your last merge might have missed some changes... Travis CI is failing: https://travis-ci.org/apache/accumulo/jobs/425445192
@keith-turner and @ctubbsii Checkout b79c429.
@ctubbsii Looks like the tests I fixed are passing now on Apache Jenkins. ReadWriteIT is timing out, which I believe is more typical.
@ctubbsii and @milleruntime I made some updates based on comments.  I looked at the new API and tried to make it more consistent.
Here is what they look like: https://github.com/apache/accumulo-website/pull/107
@ctubbsii since this is security related, you OK with this?

tl;dr I think this is a bad idea (see my case below). However, I'm open to being convinced... Is there a some use case which cannot be satisfied with the current checks? What's driving this?

****

While it may not be necessary to provide confidentiality of the truststore, "validation that the JKS is the JKS that the user expects" is the very definition of integrity. Passphrases on java keystores (including truststores) provide both confidentiality and integrity. So the log message is incorrect: it *is* providing security value, by enforcing the use of integrity beyond file system permissions.

While we don't necessarily need to enforce the use of integrity measures by requiring a passphrase (we could leave that to the user), I think it's better that we do... it encourages good security practices, and ensures that they must take active measures to select less integrity (by choosing a weak and well-known password like "changeit"). If we do what you propose, the default posture for the user will be shifted from one of having integrity and needing to take steps to reduce integrity, to one of not having integrity and needing to take action to provide integrity. I'm inclined to prefer the former, which is what we have now.

I actually think there might be other issues with this boolean, though... like the fact that we assume if not everything is set, then we didn't want HTTPS. However, I think we should check if *any* item is non-empty, and if if any is non-empty, then assume we do want HTTPS, and then check that we have everything else we need and fail if we don't rather than fall back to insecure HTTP.

If we change that logic a bit, then it might make sense to consider the passphrases optional (but I'd still recommend to set them).

Another problem I noticed... I'm not sure we're checking for CLIENT_AUTH... we should be able to set that to lock down the monitor to only trusted users. Maybe I just didn't see it... I thought it was there, but I could be wrong.

> While it may not be necessary to provide confidentiality of the truststore, "validation that the JKS is the JKS that the user expects" is the very definition of integrity.

Yes, thanks for re-defining integrity for me ;). Thought it was obvious that's what I was describing. No security, just integrity of the JKS.

> So the log message is incorrect: it is providing security value, by enforcing the use of integrity beyond file system permissions.

Truststores, in this context, do not contain private material, thus there is no need to enforce confidentiality -- in fact, the typical deployment model for Java installations has a globally readable truststore.

> Thought it was obvious that's what I was describing. No security, just integrity of the JKS.

It wasn't obvious because I was/am confused by your continued phrasing which overlooks integrity as a type of security.

> Truststores, in this context, do not contain private material, thus there is no need to enforce confidentiality

I agree and said as much myself. Truststores don't need confidentiality. They do need integrity. Passphrases provide both, but truststores only need the latter.

> overlooks integrity as a type of security.

Integrity is a part of security, not "security" if you ask me. If I only give you integrity, it is not "secure". That is what I'm implying.
